INCREDIBLE SET.Let me first start out with, I'm not sure if the block came with a minor scratch or if my wife put it there before I got a chance to inspect in good lighting. I opened it all up in lighting comparable to what you see in my photos and never caught a tiny scratch on the block. The next day with daylight, I noticed it. I don't even care. It's small and maybe I'll color it in with a black paint pen or marker if I care enough. These knives are incredible.So first, like everyone else stated, they're crazy sharp. They're so sharp, my wife doesn't even want to use them. She's a tad clumsy and cut herself on the 12 year old set this replaced. That said, she gave it a shot under my supervision to do some veggie work and she was blown away.The feel and quality of these knives needs to be put in hand to understand. They feel like an artists tool. They got weight to them and a high quality feel. The steel is thicker than my last set and feels stronger. The steel goes from tip to end of handle, FULL TANG. The craftsmanship of the handle and shape of the knives is a beauty. I can't stop putting together dishes just to cut stuff, lol. They feel so good in the hand and just make you want to use them.I finally had a chance to use the "steak" knives on a pork dish I put together and it cut through like butter. They're all insanely sharp, so again be careful handling them. I washed all of them right out of the box and didn't realize I nearly sliced my sponge in half when I was done with them.So yeah, I'll just end that I'm more than satisfied with these. Replacing my 12 year old KitchenAid set never felt better. I did a lot of research prior to buying and it was a close call between going German or Japanese (made in Cali), then thought about Hattori Hanzo and how the Bride got her revenge. Japanese steel baby. These do not disappoint and you will not regret the purchase, I promise.EDIT - I want to touch up on folks with the rust problems and possibly put some fears to rest. These are stainless steel. Even the Cybertruck has owners complaining about rust. The best you can do to prevent it is immediately dry them as soon as you wash them and do not let them sit in water. Think about it, if you fear they're just going to rust out of nowhere, you would have potentially received one out of the box covered in rust. That's not how it works. More than likely the folks complaining about rust have either put them in a dish washer (use at your own risk) or let them sit in a pot of water or something and did not immediately dry them.My best advice using these is immediately wash and dry them off as soon as you use them. It's easy enough to accomplish. I see I'm cutting some pork, I pull out the Santoku knife. I use it. I immediately run it under water/soap, grab my cloth hand towel and carefully dry it off, ensuring no water is left on it and put it back in the block. This can probably solve 99% of the rust problems.

The addition of high carbon in the stainless steel and the 12 degree edge angle makes the blade very durable and sharp as well as rust resistant. It came out of the box razor sharp. One thing to be aware of is that "pakkawood" is not a solid wood species. The handle is made laminating sheets of real wood veneer and then gluing them together with a resin. This actually makes the handle less porous and harder than if it was a solid piece of wood...that's a good thing. Also, be aware that the blade is not a true Damascus steel blade. It is just laser etched with a pattern to look like it. I don't mind as it's still a very quality blade and still looks cool.
